segment.source: Use Internet Explorer to collect data on computers running Windows Internet Explorer 8 through Internet Explorer 11 on Windows 10, Windows 8.1, or Windows 7.
segment.target: Use Internet Explorer to collect data on computers running Windows Internet Explorer 8 through Internet Explorer 11 on Windows 10, Windows 8.1, or Windows 7.

segment.target: Collect data using Enterprise Site Discovery

segment.source: Collect data using Enterprise Site Discovery
segment.target: Collect data using Enterprise Site Discovery

segment.target: Applies to:

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows 8.1
segment.target: Windows 8.1

segment.source: Windows 7 with Service Pack 1 (SP1)
segment.target: Windows 7 with Service Pack 1 (SP1)

segment.source: Use Internet Explorer to collect data on computers running Windows Internet Explorer 8 through Internet Explorer 11 on Windows 10, Windows 8.1, or Windows 7.
segment.target: Use Internet Explorer to collect data on computers running Windows Internet Explorer 8 through Internet Explorer 11 on Windows 10, Windows 8.1, or Windows 7.

segment.source: This inventory information helps you build a list of websites used by your company so you can make more informed decisions about your IE deployments, including figuring out which sites might be at risk or require overhauls during future upgrades.
segment.target: This inventory information helps you build a list of websites used by your company so you can make more informed decisions about your IE deployments, including figuring out which sites might be at risk or require overhauls during future upgrades.

segment.source: Before you begin
segment.target: Before you begin

segment.source: Before you start, you need to make sure you have the following:
segment.target: Before you start, you need to make sure you have the following:

segment.source: Latest cumulative security update (for all supported versions of Internet Explorer):
segment.target: Latest cumulative security update (for all supported versions of Internet Explorer):

segment.source: Go to the Microsoft Security Bulletin page, and change the filter to Windows Internet Explorer 11.
segment.target: Go to the Microsoft Security Bulletin page, and change the filter to Windows Internet Explorer 11.

segment.source: microsoft security bulletin techcenter
segment.target: microsoft security bulletin techcenter

segment.source: Click the title of the latest cumulative security update, and then scroll down to the Affected software table.
segment.target: Click the title of the latest cumulative security update, and then scroll down to the Affected software table.

segment.source: affected software section
segment.target: affected software section

segment.source: Click the link that represents both your operating system version and Internet Explorer 11, and then follow the instructions in the How to get this update section.
segment.target: Click the link that represents both your operating system version and Internet Explorer 11, and then follow the instructions in the How to get this update section.

segment.source: Setup and configuration package, including:
segment.target: Setup and configuration package, including:

segment.source: Configuration-related PowerShell scripts
segment.target: Configuration-related PowerShell scripts

segment.source: IETelemetry.mof file
segment.target: IETelemetry.mof file

segment.source: Sample System Center 2012 report templates
segment.target: Sample System Center 2012 report templates

segment.source: You must use System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager or later for these samples to work.
segment.target: You must use System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager or later for these samples to work.

segment.source: Both the PowerShell script and the Managed Object Format (.MOF) file need to be copied to the same location on the client device, before you run the scripts.
segment.target: Both the PowerShell script and the Managed Object Format (.MOF) file need to be copied to the same location on the client device, before you run the scripts.

segment.source: What data is collected?
segment.target: What data is collected?

segment.source: Data is collected on the configuration characteristics of IE and the sites it browses, as shown here.
segment.target: Data is collected on the configuration characteristics of IE and the sites it browses, as shown here.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: By default, IE doesn’t collect this data; you have to turn this feature on if you want to use it.
segment.target: By default, IE doesn’t collect this data; you have to turn this feature on if you want to use it.

segment.source: After you turn on this feature, data is collected on all sites visited by IE, except during InPrivate sessions.
segment.target: After you turn on this feature, data is collected on all sites visited by IE, except during InPrivate sessions.

segment.source: The data collection process is silent, so there’s no notification to the employee.
segment.target: The data collection process is silent, so there’s no notification to the employee.

segment.source: Therefore, you must get consent from the employee before you start collecting info.
segment.target: Therefore, you must get consent from the employee before you start collecting info.

segment.source: You must also make sure that using this feature complies with all applicable local laws and regulatory requirements.
segment.target: You must also make sure that using this feature complies with all applicable local laws and regulatory requirements.

segment.source: Where is the data stored and how do I collect it?
segment.target: Where is the data stored and how do I collect it?

segment.source: The data is stored locally, in an industry-standard WMI class, .MOF file or in an XML file, depending on your configuration.
segment.target: The data is stored locally, in an industry-standard WMI class, .MOF file or in an XML file, depending on your configuration.

segment.source: This file remains on the client computer until it’s collected.
segment.target: This file remains on the client computer until it’s collected.

segment.source: To collect the files, we recommend:
segment.target: To collect the files, we recommend:

segment.source: WMI file.
segment.target: WMI file.

segment.source: Use Microsoft Configuration Manager or any agent that can read the contents of a WMI class on your computer.
segment.target: Use Microsoft Configuration Manager or any agent that can read the contents of a WMI class on your computer.

segment.source: XML file.
segment.target: XML file.

segment.source: Any agent that works with XML can be used.
segment.target: Any agent that works with XML can be used.

segment.source: WMI Site Discovery suggestions
segment.target: WMI Site Discovery suggestions

segment.source: We recommend that you collect your data for at most a month at a time, to capture a user’s typical workflow.
segment.target: We recommend that you collect your data for at most a month at a time, to capture a user’s typical workflow.

segment.source: We don’t recommend collecting data longer than that because the data is stored in a WMI provider and can fill up your computer’s hard drive.
segment.target: We don’t recommend collecting data longer than that because the data is stored in a WMI provider and can fill up your computer’s hard drive.

segment.source: You may also want to collect data only for pilot users or a representative sample of people, instead of turning this feature on for everyone in your company.
segment.target: You may also want to collect data only for pilot users or a representative sample of people, instead of turning this feature on for everyone in your company.

segment.source: On average, a website generates about 250bytes of data for each visit, causing only a minor impact to Internet Explorer’s performance.
segment.target: On average, a website generates about 250bytes of data for each visit, causing only a minor impact to Internet Explorer’s performance.

segment.source: Over the course of a month, collecting data from 20 sites per day from 1,000 users, you’ll get about 150MB of data:
segment.target: Over the course of a month, collecting data from 20 sites per day from 1,000 users, you’ll get about 150MB of data:

segment.source: 250bytes (per site visit) 20sites/day 30days = (approximately) 150KB 1000users = (approximately) 150MB.
segment.target: 250bytes (per site visit) 20sites/day 30days = (approximately) 150KB 1000users = (approximately) 150MB.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: The data collection process is silent, so there’s no notification to the employee.
segment.target: The data collection process is silent, so there’s no notification to the employee.

segment.source: Therefore, you must get consent from the employee before you start collecting info.
segment.target: Therefore, you must get consent from the employee before you start collecting info.

segment.source: You must also make sure that using this feature complies with all applicable local laws and regulatory requirements.
segment.target: You must also make sure that using this feature complies with all applicable local laws and regulatory requirements.

segment.source: Getting ready to use Enterprise Site Discovery
segment.target: Getting ready to use Enterprise Site Discovery

segment.source: Before you can start to collect your data, you must run the provided PowerShell script (IETelemetrySetUp.ps1) on your client devices to start generating the site discovery data and to set up a place to store this data locally.
segment.target: Before you can start to collect your data, you must run the provided PowerShell script (IETelemetrySetUp.ps1) on your client devices to start generating the site discovery data and to set up a place to store this data locally.

segment.source: Then, you must start collecting the site discovery data from the client devices, using one of these three options:
segment.target: Then, you must start collecting the site discovery data from the client devices, using one of these three options:

segment.source: Collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor, while connecting to a client device.
segment.target: Collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor, while connecting to a client device.

segment.source: -OR-
segment.target: -OR-

segment.source: Collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor with a .MOF import file.
segment.target: Collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor with a .MOF import file.

segment.source: -OR-
segment.target: -OR-

segment.source: Collect your hardware inventory using the SMS\DEF.MOF file (System Center Configuration Manager 2007 only)
segment.target: Collect your hardware inventory using the SMS\DEF.MOF file (System Center Configuration Manager 2007 only)

segment.source: WMI only: Running the PowerShell script to compile the .MOF file and to update security privileges
segment.target: WMI only: Running the PowerShell script to compile the .MOF file and to update security privileges

segment.source: You need to set up your computers for data collection by running the provided PowerShell script (IETelemetrySetUp.ps1) to compile the .mof file and to update security privileges for the new WMI classes.
segment.target: You need to set up your computers for data collection by running the provided PowerShell script (IETelemetrySetUp.ps1) to compile the .mof file and to update security privileges for the new WMI classes.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: You must run this script if you’re using WMI as your data output.
segment.target: You must run this script if you’re using WMI as your data output.

segment.source: It's not necessary if you're using XML as your data output.
segment.target: It's not necessary if you're using XML as your data output.

segment.source: To set up Enterprise Site Discovery
segment.target: To set up Enterprise Site Discovery

segment.source: Start PowerShell in elevated mode (using admin privileges) and run IETElemetrySetUp.ps1 by by-passing the PowerShell execution policy, using this command: .
segment.target: Start PowerShell in elevated mode (using admin privileges) and run IETElemetrySetUp.ps1 by by-passing the PowerShell execution policy, using this command: .

segment.source: For more info, see about Execution Policies.
segment.target: For more info, see about Execution Policies.

segment.source: WMI only: Set up your firewall for WMI data
segment.target: WMI only: Set up your firewall for WMI data

segment.source: If you choose to use WMI as your data output, you need to make sure that your WMI data can travel through your firewall for the domain.
segment.target: If you choose to use WMI as your data output, you need to make sure that your WMI data can travel through your firewall for the domain.

segment.source: If you’re sure, you can skip this section; otherwise, follow these steps:
segment.target: If you’re sure, you can skip this section; otherwise, follow these steps:

segment.source: To set up your firewall
segment.target: To set up your firewall

segment.source: In Control Panel, click System and Security, and then click Windows Firewall.
segment.target: In Control Panel, click System and Security, and then click Windows Firewall.

segment.source: In the left pane, click Allow an app or feature through Windows Firewall and scroll down to check the box for Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI).
segment.target: In the left pane, click Allow an app or feature through Windows Firewall and scroll down to check the box for Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI).

segment.source: Restart your computer to start collecting your WMI data.
segment.target: Restart your computer to start collecting your WMI data.

segment.source: Use PowerShell to finish setting up Enterprise Site Discovery
segment.target: Use PowerShell to finish setting up Enterprise Site Discovery

segment.source: You can determine which zones or domains are used for data collection, using PowerShell.
segment.target: You can determine which zones or domains are used for data collection, using PowerShell.

segment.source: If you don’t want to use PowerShell, you can do this using Group Policy.
segment.target: If you don’t want to use PowerShell, you can do this using Group Policy.

segment.source: For more info, see Use Group Policy to finish setting up Enterprise Site Discovery.
segment.target: For more info, see Use Group Policy to finish setting up Enterprise Site Discovery.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: The .ps1 file updates turn on Enterprise Site Discovery and WMI collection for all users on a device.
segment.target: The .ps1 file updates turn on Enterprise Site Discovery and WMI collection for all users on a device.

segment.source: Domain allow list.
segment.target: Domain allow list.

segment.source: If you have a domain allow list, a comma-separated list of domains that should have this feature turned on, you should use this process.
segment.target: If you have a domain allow list, a comma-separated list of domains that should have this feature turned on, you should use this process.

segment.source: Zone allow list.
segment.target: Zone allow list.

segment.source: If you have a zone allow list, a comma-separated list of zones that should have this feature turned on, you should use this process.
segment.target: If you have a zone allow list, a comma-separated list of zones that should have this feature turned on, you should use this process.

segment.source: To set up data collection using a domain allow list
segment.target: To set up data collection using a domain allow list

segment.source: Start PowerShell in elevated mode (using admin privileges) and run IETElemetrySetUp.ps1, using this command: .
segment.target: Start PowerShell in elevated mode (using admin privileges) and run IETElemetrySetUp.ps1, using this command: .

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Wildcards, like .microsoft.com, aren’t supported.
segment.target: Wildcards, like .microsoft.com, aren’t supported.

segment.source: To set up data collection using a zone allow list
segment.target: To set up data collection using a zone allow list

segment.source: Start PowerShell in elevated mode (using admin privileges) and run IETElemetrySetUp.ps1, using this command: .
segment.target: Start PowerShell in elevated mode (using admin privileges) and run IETElemetrySetUp.ps1, using this command: .

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Only Computer, Intranet, TrustedSites, Internet, and RestrictedSites are supported.
segment.target: Only Computer, Intranet, TrustedSites, Internet, and RestrictedSites are supported.

segment.source: Use Group Policy to finish setting up Enterprise Site Discovery
segment.target: Use Group Policy to finish setting up Enterprise Site Discovery

segment.source: You can use Group Policy to finish setting up Enterprise Site Discovery.
segment.target: You can use Group Policy to finish setting up Enterprise Site Discovery.

segment.source: If you don’t want to use Group Policy, you can do this using PowerShell.
segment.target: If you don’t want to use Group Policy, you can do this using PowerShell.

segment.source: For more info, see Use Powershell to finish setting up Enterprise Site Discovery.
segment.target: For more info, see Use Powershell to finish setting up Enterprise Site Discovery.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: All of the Group Policy settings can be used individually or as a group.
segment.target: All of the Group Policy settings can be used individually or as a group.

segment.source: To set up Enterprise Site Discovery using Group Policy
segment.target: To set up Enterprise Site Discovery using Group Policy

segment.source: Open your Group Policy editor, and go to these new settings:
segment.target: Open your Group Policy editor, and go to these new settings:

segment.source: Setting name and location
segment.target: Setting name and location

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Options
segment.target: Options

segment.source: Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Turn on Site Discovery WMI output
segment.target: Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Turn on Site Discovery WMI output

segment.source: Writes collected data to a WMI class, which can be aggregated using a client-management solution like Configuration Manager.
segment.target: Writes collected data to a WMI class, which can be aggregated using a client-management solution like Configuration Manager.

segment.source: On.
segment.target: On.

segment.source: Turns on WMI recording.
segment.target: Turns on WMI recording.

segment.source: Off.
segment.target: Off.

segment.source: Turns off WMI recording.
segment.target: Turns off WMI recording.

segment.source: Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Turn on Site Discovery XML output
segment.target: Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Turn on Site Discovery XML output

segment.source: Writes collected data to an XML file, which is stored in your specified location.
segment.target: Writes collected data to an XML file, which is stored in your specified location.

segment.source: XML file path.
segment.target: XML file path.

segment.source: Including this turns on XML recording.
segment.target: Including this turns on XML recording.

segment.source: Blank.
segment.target: Blank.

segment.source: Turns off XML recording.
segment.target: Turns off XML recording.

segment.source: Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Limit Site Discovery output by Zone
segment.target: Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Limit Site Discovery output by Zone

segment.source: Manages which zone can collect data.
segment.target: Manages which zone can collect data.

segment.source: To specify which zones can collect data, you must include a binary number that represents your selected zones, based on this order:
segment.target: To specify which zones can collect data, you must include a binary number that represents your selected zones, based on this order:

segment.source: 0 – Restricted Sites zone
segment.target: 0 – Restricted Sites zone

segment.source: 0 – Internet zone
segment.target: 0 – Internet zone

segment.source: 0 – Trusted Sites zone
segment.target: 0 – Trusted Sites zone

segment.source: 0 – Local Intranet zone
segment.target: 0 – Local Intranet zone

segment.source: 0 – Local Machine zone
segment.target: 0 – Local Machine zone

segment.source: Example 1: Include only the Local Intranet zone
segment.target: Example 1: Include only the Local Intranet zone

segment.source: Binary representation: 00010, based on:
segment.target: Binary representation: 00010, based on:

segment.source: 0 – Restricted Sites zone
segment.target: 0 – Restricted Sites zone

segment.source: 0 – Internet zone
segment.target: 0 – Internet zone

segment.source: 0 – Trusted Sites zone
segment.target: 0 – Trusted Sites zone

segment.source: 1 – Local Intranet zone
segment.target: 1 – Local Intranet zone

segment.source: 0 – Local Machine zone
segment.target: 0 – Local Machine zone

segment.source: Example 2: Include only the Restricted Sites, Trusted Sites, and Local Intranet zones
segment.target: Example 2: Include only the Restricted Sites, Trusted Sites, and Local Intranet zones

segment.source: Binary representation: 10110, based on:
segment.target: Binary representation: 10110, based on:

segment.source: 1 – Restricted Sites zone
segment.target: 1 – Restricted Sites zone

segment.source: 0 – Internet zone
segment.target: 0 – Internet zone

segment.source: 1 – Trusted Sites zone
segment.target: 1 – Trusted Sites zone

segment.source: 1 – Local Intranet zone
segment.target: 1 – Local Intranet zone

segment.source: 1 – Local Machine zone
segment.target: 1 – Local Machine zone

segment.source: Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Limit Site Discovery output by domain
segment.target: Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Limit Site Discovery output by domain

segment.source: Manages which domains can collect data
segment.target: Manages which domains can collect data

segment.source: To specify which domains can collect data, you must include your selected domains, one domain per line, in the provided box.
segment.target: To specify which domains can collect data, you must include your selected domains, one domain per line, in the provided box.

segment.source: It should look like:
segment.target: It should look like:

segment.source: microsoft.sharepoint.com
segment.target: microsoft.sharepoint.com

segment.source: outlook.com
segment.target: outlook.com

segment.source: onedrive.com
segment.target: onedrive.com

segment.source: timecard.contoso.com
segment.target: timecard.contoso.com

segment.source: LOBApp.contoso.com
segment.target: LOBApp.contoso.com

segment.source: Combining WMI and XML Group Policy settings
segment.target: Combining WMI and XML Group Policy settings

segment.source: You can use both the WMI and XML settings individually or together, based on:
segment.target: You can use both the WMI and XML settings individually or together, based on:

segment.source: To turn off Enterprise Site Discovery
segment.target: To turn off Enterprise Site Discovery

segment.source: Turn on Site Discovery WMI output: Off
segment.target: Turn on Site Discovery WMI output: Off

segment.source: Turn on Site Discovery XML output: Blank
segment.target: Turn on Site Discovery XML output: Blank

segment.source: To turn on WMI recording only
segment.target: To turn on WMI recording only

segment.source: Turn on Site Discovery WMI output: On
segment.target: Turn on Site Discovery WMI output: On

segment.source: Turn on Site Discovery XML output: Blank
segment.target: Turn on Site Discovery XML output: Blank

segment.source: To turn on XML recording only
segment.target: To turn on XML recording only

segment.source: Turn on Site Discovery WMI output: Off
segment.target: Turn on Site Discovery WMI output: Off

segment.source: Turn on Site Discovery XML output: XML file path
segment.target: Turn on Site Discovery XML output: XML file path

segment.source: To turn on both WMI and XML recording
segment.target: To turn on both WMI and XML recording

segment.source: Turn on Site Discovery WMI output: On
segment.target: Turn on Site Discovery WMI output: On

segment.source: Turn on Site Discovery XML output: XML file path
segment.target: Turn on Site Discovery XML output: XML file path

segment.source: Use Configuration Manager to collect your data
segment.target: Use Configuration Manager to collect your data

segment.source: After you’ve collected your data, you’ll need to get the local files off of your employee’s computers.
segment.target: After you’ve collected your data, you’ll need to get the local files off of your employee’s computers.

segment.source: To do this, use the hardware inventory process in Configuration Manager, using one of these options:
segment.target: To do this, use the hardware inventory process in Configuration Manager, using one of these options:

segment.source: Collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor, while connecting to a client device.
segment.target: Collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor, while connecting to a client device.

segment.source: -OR-
segment.target: -OR-

segment.source: Collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor with a .MOF import file.
segment.target: Collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor with a .MOF import file.

segment.source: -OR-
segment.target: -OR-

segment.source: Collect your hardware inventory using the SMS\DEF.MOF file (System Center Configuration Manager 2007 only)
segment.target: Collect your hardware inventory using the SMS\DEF.MOF file (System Center Configuration Manager 2007 only)

segment.source: Collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor while connected to a client device
segment.target: Collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor while connected to a client device

segment.source: You can collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor, while you’re connected to your client devices.
segment.target: You can collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor, while you’re connected to your client devices.

segment.source: To collect your inventory
segment.target: To collect your inventory

segment.source: From the Configuration Manager, click Administration, click Client Settings, double-click Default Client Settings, click Hardware Inventory, and then click Set Classes.
segment.target: From the Configuration Manager, click Administration, click Client Settings, double-click Default Client Settings, click Hardware Inventory, and then click Set Classes.

segment.source: Configuration Manager, showing the hardware inventory settings for client computers
segment.target: Configuration Manager, showing the hardware inventory settings for client computers

segment.source: Click Add, click Connect, and connect to a computer that has completed the setup process and has already existing classes.
segment.target: Click Add, click Connect, and connect to a computer that has completed the setup process and has already existing classes.

segment.source: Change the WMI Namespace to , and click Connect.
segment.target: Change the WMI Namespace to , and click Connect.

segment.source: Configuration Manager, with the Connect to Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) box
segment.target: Configuration Manager, with the Connect to Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) box

segment.source: Select the check boxes next to the following classes, and then click OK:
segment.target: Select the check boxes next to the following classes, and then click OK:

segment.source: IESystemInfo
segment.target: IESystemInfo

segment.source: IEURLInfo
segment.target: IEURLInfo

segment.source: IECountInfo
segment.target: IECountInfo

segment.source: Click OK to close the default windows.
segment.target: Click OK to close the default windows.

segment.source: Your environment is now ready to collect your hardware inventory and review the sample reports.
segment.target: Your environment is now ready to collect your hardware inventory and review the sample reports.

segment.source: Collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor with a .MOF import file
segment.target: Collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor with a .MOF import file

segment.source: You can collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor and a .MOF import file.
segment.target: You can collect your hardware inventory using the MOF Editor and a .MOF import file.

segment.source: To collect your inventory
segment.target: To collect your inventory

segment.source: From the Configuration Manager, click Administration, click Client Settings, double-click Default Client Settings, click Hardware Inventory, and then click Set Classes.
segment.target: From the Configuration Manager, click Administration, click Client Settings, double-click Default Client Settings, click Hardware Inventory, and then click Set Classes.

segment.source: Click Import, choose the MOF file from the downloaded package we provided, and click Open.
segment.target: Click Import, choose the MOF file from the downloaded package we provided, and click Open.

segment.source: Pick the inventory items to install, and then click Import.
segment.target: Pick the inventory items to install, and then click Import.

segment.source: Click OK to close the default windows.
segment.target: Click OK to close the default windows.

segment.source: Your environment is now ready to collect your hardware inventory and review the sample reports.
segment.target: Your environment is now ready to collect your hardware inventory and review the sample reports.

segment.source: Collect your hardware inventory using the SMS\DEF.MOF file (System Center Configuration Manager 2007 only)
segment.target: Collect your hardware inventory using the SMS\DEF.MOF file (System Center Configuration Manager 2007 only)

segment.source: You can collect your hardware inventory using the using the Systems Management Server (SMS\DEF.MOF) file.
segment.target: You can collect your hardware inventory using the using the Systems Management Server (SMS\DEF.MOF) file.

segment.source: Editing this file lets you collect your data for System Center Configuration Manager 2007.
segment.target: Editing this file lets you collect your data for System Center Configuration Manager 2007.

segment.source: If you aren’t using this version of Configuration Manager, you won’t want to use this option.
segment.target: If you aren’t using this version of Configuration Manager, you won’t want to use this option.

segment.source: To collect your inventory
segment.target: To collect your inventory

segment.source: Using a text editor like Notepad, open the SMS\DEF.MOF file, located in your directory.
segment.target: Using a text editor like Notepad, open the SMS\DEF.MOF file, located in your directory.

segment.source: Add this text to the end of the file:
segment.target: Add this text to the end of the file:

segment.source: Save the file and close it to the same location.
segment.target: Save the file and close it to the same location.

segment.source: Your environment is now ready to collect your hardware inventory and review the sample reports.
segment.target: Your environment is now ready to collect your hardware inventory and review the sample reports.

segment.source: View the sample reports with your collected data
segment.target: View the sample reports with your collected data

segment.source: The sample reports, SCCM Report Sample – ActiveX.rdl and SCCM Report Sample – Site Discovery.rdl, work with System Center 2012, so you can review your collected data.
segment.target: The sample reports, SCCM Report Sample – ActiveX.rdl and SCCM Report Sample – Site Discovery.rdl, work with System Center 2012, so you can review your collected data.

segment.source: SCCM Report Sample – ActiveX.rdl
segment.target: SCCM Report Sample – ActiveX.rdl

segment.source: Gives you a list of all of the ActiveX-related sites visited by the client computer.
segment.target: Gives you a list of all of the ActiveX-related sites visited by the client computer.

segment.source: ActiveX.rdl report, lists all ActiveX-related sites visited by the client computer
segment.target: ActiveX.rdl report, lists all ActiveX-related sites visited by the client computer

segment.source: SCCM Report Sample – Site Discovery.rdl
segment.target: SCCM Report Sample – Site Discovery.rdl

segment.source: Gives you a list of all of the sites visited by the client computer.
segment.target: Gives you a list of all of the sites visited by the client computer.

segment.source: Site Discovery.rdl report, lists all websites visited by the client computer
segment.target: Site Discovery.rdl report, lists all websites visited by the client computer

segment.source: View the collected XML data
segment.target: View the collected XML data

segment.source: After the XML files are created, you can use your own solutions to extract and parse the data.
segment.target: After the XML files are created, you can use your own solutions to extract and parse the data.

segment.source: The data will look like:
segment.target: The data will look like:

segment.source: You can import this XML data into the correct version of the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager, automatically adding the included sites to your Enterprise Mode site list.
segment.target: You can import this XML data into the correct version of the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager, automatically adding the included sites to your Enterprise Mode site list.

segment.source: To add your XML data to your Enterprise Mode site list
segment.target: To add your XML data to your Enterprise Mode site list

segment.source: Open the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager, click File, and then click Bulk add from file.
segment.target: Open the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager, click File, and then click Bulk add from file.

segment.source: Enterprise Mode Site List Manager with Bulk add from file option
segment.target: Enterprise Mode Site List Manager with Bulk add from file option

segment.source: Go to your XML file to add the included sites to the tool, and then click Open.
segment.target: Go to your XML file to add the included sites to the tool, and then click Open.

segment.source: Each site is validated and if successful, added to the global site list when you click OK to close the menu.
segment.target: Each site is validated and if successful, added to the global site list when you click OK to close the menu.

segment.source: If a site doesn’t pass validation, you can try to fix the issues or pick the site and click Add to list to ignore the validation problem.
segment.target: If a site doesn’t pass validation, you can try to fix the issues or pick the site and click Add to list to ignore the validation problem.

segment.source: For more information about fixing validation problems, see Fix validation problems using the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager.
segment.target: For more information about fixing validation problems, see Fix validation problems using the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager.

segment.source: Click OK to close the Bulk add sites to the list menu.
segment.target: Click OK to close the Bulk add sites to the list menu.

segment.source: Turn off data collection on your client devices
segment.target: Turn off data collection on your client devices

segment.source: After you’ve collected your data, you’ll need to turn Enterprise Site Discovery off.
segment.target: After you’ve collected your data, you’ll need to turn Enterprise Site Discovery off.

segment.source: To stop collecting data, using PowerShell
segment.target: To stop collecting data, using PowerShell

segment.source: On your client computer, start Windows PowerShell in elevated mode (using admin privileges) and run , using this command: .
segment.target: On your client computer, start Windows PowerShell in elevated mode (using admin privileges) and run , using this command: .

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Turning off data collection only disables the Enterprise Site Discovery feature – all data already written to WMI stays on your employee’s computer.
segment.target: Turning off data collection only disables the Enterprise Site Discovery feature – all data already written to WMI stays on your employee’s computer.

segment.source: To stop collecting data, using Group Policy
segment.target: To stop collecting data, using Group Policy

originalData.data: `Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Turn on Site Discovery WMI output`

segment.source: Open your Group Policy editor, go to , and click Off.
segment.target: Open your Group Policy editor, go to , and click Off.

originalData.data: `Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Turn on Site Discovery XML output`

segment.source: Go to , and clear the file path location.
segment.target: Go to , and clear the file path location.

segment.source: Delete already stored data from client computers
segment.target: Delete already stored data from client computers

segment.source: You can completely remove the data stored on your employee’s computers.
segment.target: You can completely remove the data stored on your employee’s computers.

segment.source: To delete all existing data
segment.target: To delete all existing data

segment.target: On the client computer, start PowerShell in elevated mode (using admin privileges) and run these four commands:
